The A320 pilot reported seeing a white quadcopter drone `` flash past '' the aircraft while travelling south of Brookmans Park last August . No avoiding action was possible due to a lack of radar coverage in the area , the pilot added . The plane flew over St Helens , Liverpool and Runcorn , but the drone operator , which was not identified , never got close to the aircraft . At 10. 30pm , the A320 headed west at 1755m , just under 2,000ft , when the drone , which was now flying south , turned around it , travelling over Tottman Moss nature reserve in Knowsley , the pilot said. The drone then disappeared from the radar again at 11. 15pm . It flew north at first , passing near Ellesmere Port and Liverpool , then flew east at first followed by a sharp turn to return southward before crossing the A59 at Tottman Moss , the pilot claimed . The drone never alighted at any point in the UK . In the past , A320 flights to and from Manchester city centre had been disrupted after drone operators flew drones in the area .

The Port Talbot-based Specific innovation centre is working on the concept of `` buildings as power stations '' . The project involves Tata Steel , Swansea and Cardiff universities , and Microsoft . It is expected to produce new , more efficient methods of generating renewable electricity for use in steel smelting and other industrial processes . The idea is to produce a `` built-in `` source of energy used anywhere and it could be used to produce hydrogen so that steel production could be carried out entirely on the site . The concept is to build a `` network of micro-grids ` ' , a term coined by Martin Cooper of the Royal Academy of Engineering . Micro-grids are the collection of power stations and other critical , non-electrical , devices linked together by high tech communication which can be operated and monitored centrally to provide uninterrupted electricity supply during a blackout . The idea is that the micro-grids can respond in a near instant way by switching on the power and stabilising it until the blackout is over . This may be important for industries with large amounts of power use such as steel .

A regulation banning a practice known as `` moving under braking '' was adopted last year after drivers complained about Red Bull 's Max Verstappen . But governing body the FIA is reviewing a second rule that makes driving under the influence harder to detect . Last week , the Dutchman and his team crashed out when he tried to pass another car in the first corner of the Belgian Grand Prix . At the time of the crash , his team mate Daniel Ricciardo was in the lead . What is the law against moving under braking ? F1 has banned the `` moving under braking and accelerating , '' or `` MUBA '' trick since 2013 . This means that drivers must stay within the lines whenever possible and must move the brake pedal away from the accelerator when going into a corner . Moving under braking can make the braking point appear earlier . This is against the rules . At some circuits , this rule was relaxed to allow teams to use this rule to overtake . This year , this is again being looked at .

A study , in the British Medical Journal , showed a sudden fall in antidepressant prescriptions and a rise in suicide attempts after media reports of the connection . The Lancet and The BMJ publications cited there are quite shocking . The researchers tried to look for any changes before 2000 and after 2006 , when the number of suicide attempts increased the most . They found it was possible to statistically control for other risk factors , but there was one surprising finding : the jump seemed to happen in the period just before the media stories , when depression was considered by some to be the number 1 cause of suicide . In other words , the media coverage had made depression seem more dangerous and more common , in the hope of promoting more research , rather than to warn people off using antidepressants . In other words , the media is in bed with drug companies and doctors , and so they are able to distort research . And as with all science , you know it has been distorted when they run clinical trials using a certain set of drugs for a certain set of symptoms and then find that the drugs do n't work.

Bouygues was created in the 1950s , when founder Antoine Chazin , who died several years ago , created a holding company for the operations of three companies : Bouygues Telecom and two of its subsidiaries , Grou. fr ( an Internet business ) and Bouygues Media ( an advertising and marketing business ) . Bouygues Media will run Bouygues ' current business under this holding company . As a result of the merger , SFR could also gain a major media investment company and potentially a significant share of France 's mobile satellite business . The proposed merger is expected to be completed in the first half of 2007 , according to various reports and people close to the companies .

Cleveland Police allegedly tried to monitor the activity of six people after a 2012 front-page story in the Northern Echo . While none of the journalists named in the affidavit have ever publicly confirmed that they were targeted by police , there are indications that they had been . Their apparent criminal activity may have contributed to the decision not to prosecute them . There are indications that the surveillance of the journalists may have taken place before 2011 . However , the surveillance allegations make no mention that any police officer was named as planning or carrying out the surveillance . The journalists who have been named in the affidavit argue that such use of surveillance powers violates the principles of equality before the law and constitutes interference with their and others ' right to privacy .

Keeping older people at work can also boost wages for younger employees , argues Ros Altmann , the government-appointed champion for older workers . Her report suggests that extending working life can lead to healthier and more productive workers , who help retain jobs for younger workers . As people age , their ability to work decreases , says Altmann . So older workers can make the biggest contribution not just to productivity gains , but also to social security . We need a flexible workplace policy to support older workers , says Altmann , a senior vice-president for human resources and corporate citizenship at Barclays . We are talking about people who are in a precarious situation , often on short-time contracts , who get paid less than younger workers who do n't stay as long . For example , older people are paid less than those aged 22 to 24 . In the United States , older workers make up half the workforce , and a quarter of all employees aged 55 and over . Older workers have to keep working to have social security for retirement , the report says .

The bank says its phone and mobile banking customers will no longer have to remember a password or memorable places and dates to access accounts . Barclays has already introduced an app to provide financial news and advice in an 'app-in-the-phone ' experience . The new service could potentially reduce the need for users to sign on with their physical account credentials at ATMs and through their physical branches . The bank , for example , currently charges a physical branch visit fee of £5 , or the equivalent in other countries . But this fee is waived for cash card holders who access cash via an app . This move comes against the background of financial services being increasingly digitised . In the US , more than 90 million banking credentials have been replaced by technology . The move also comes at a time when cyber-security experts predict that in the next 10 years alone , the cost of data breaches will reduce annually by two thirds . Barclays says that customers may continue to use their current passwords for other services but it will soon begin providing customers with the option of using a password-free experience which it calls 'passwordless ' . The feature will initially be offered to customers at Barclays ' banking centres and select call centres .
